job_title: IT Manager
pros: Loved working for TAMU because I am a TAMU graduate and have always loved the university. Getting to stay close to something I love so dearly was awesome. Surrounded by a lot of very knowledgeable experts who are very good at what they do - great learning experience.
cons: As an Intern I worked hard in my position hoping that it would in due time turn into a full-time position. Half-way through my internship my supervisor (IT Admin for my department) resigned on a Friday afternoon which left me (by myself) to handle all Administrative duties. The department chose not to hire a replacement for him and told me that I would be the shoe in for the position as soon as I graduated (this happened in January). I graduated in May and did not receive a promotion - merely remained part-time Helpdesk/Administrator. September 1 rolled around and they notified me I was being let go in a week. No correspondence as to why was ever given. Two weeks after I was let go they hired a new Administrator. While I feel like I learned a lot having to fend for myself in that environment, I feel like they could have handled the situation a whole lot better. I feel as if I was just a cheap place holder for them and that they led me on to make sure I stuck around until they found a replacement.

review_title: Tough job but the experience is great
job_title: Resident Advisor in College Station, TX
pros: Being an RA is one of the highest paying jobs on campus (behind driving buses) but you earn that paycheck. You learn names, spend lots of time training, and have to work at odd hours. However, you learn so much about being professional. You'll become proficient at answering phones and emails very quickly. You have to learn how to submit paperwork efficiently and effectively. Your time management will improve quickly because it has to if you want to pass your classes. You become close with everyone you work with and live with almost overnight. The best parts about this job are making lots of friends, being a support system for students, making name tags for doors, and completing bulletin boards in your building.
cons: Sometimes it can all be very overwhelming. You have an excessive amount of things to do all year. However if you can survive the first and last weeks of the semester, you're golden. Make sure that if you have a problem you get it taken care of by people that will help you. Don't wait on someone to help you. Take care of it yourself.

job_title: Transit Trainer in College Station, TX
pros: The job was rewarding and fulfilling. The benefits were excellent. You typically had weekends and holidays free. You didn't really have to take the job home with you.
cons: The turnover rate was atrocious. In many instances,the student employees had the ear of management more than the staff did. There seemed to be an effort to raise the status of the student employees,while minimizing the importance of the staff. The university is applying the dual employment policy between 2 state agencies in a completely discriminatory way. In order to promote equality between all staff employees,then that policy should be applied to ALL employees that are in that circumstance. Its not. The university cherry picks who they apply it to,& who they don't. They applied it to me,but I was to find out that numerous others were allowed to be dually employed without having this policy applied to them. It is a clear cut case of university sponsored discrimination. Policy is applied to some,but not all in the same circumstance.

review_title: Close-minded entity with little concern for its employees. OK for students and tenured faculty but others, not so much.
job_title: in College Station, TX
pros: Good benefits, easy to request time off, retirement plan.
cons: Bad pay in comparison to other universities and private companies, employees are overworked with too little to show for expected level of output, too much political drama amongst those that are placed in leadership positions, caters too much to tenured faculty (support staff are disrespected, under-appreciated, and treated like slaves), bonuses have never been provided for the many years I've worked there, promotions are hard to come by at a certain level, raises are difficult to come by--often times--requiring the need to switch departments altogether, croneyism is rampant amongst the university. This is a true good ol' boy system and not a good place to work if you value innovation and commitment to change. There are no decreased tuition rates for employees, no appreciation for holding an advanced degree unless you are a tenured faculty member continuously feeding the salaries of those who are ambiguously placed in high powered positions, no free access to the university gym facilities, it costs to go to work (i.e. parking), and co-workers are overworked and disgruntled.

review_title: Communication Specialist roles in two different offices at Texas A&M University
job_title: Communications Specialist in College Station, TX
pros: Personally, I loved working with the people at Texas A&M. I mean every office has one or two who don't mesh as well. But most of the people I worked with were great. They were genuinely excited about working with and helping students (when I was in the Office of Graduate Studies) and they were passionate about making a difference and helping to improve lives via research and support (when I was in the Center on Disability and Development).
cons: The pay rate is not extremely competitive for the sometimes long hours and volume of work being done. Especially if comparing to corporate world. And in the academic world, the pay was decent but not outstanding. Working at a Center or Agency with additional outside sources of funding/grants can sometimes provide better salary rates.

job_title: Animal Caretaker in College Station, TX
pros: The University as a whole is a great reason to work there. Also, the city of College Station is a great place to live and raise a family. The University truly cares about the students and their workers. I always felt like they appreciated the work that our group did, even if we were not given bonuses or rewards. The atmosphere was very warm and respectful. The only reason why I left this job was because I graduated. This job was a student worker position and the way was great and it was a rewarding experience. Gig'em Aggies! Whooop '07.
cons: There are only a few downsides to working at Texas A&M. Probably the worst part is having to work on the weekends and on holidays for my position. This should be expected, however, because of the type of job that I held. However, it was still aggravating. Plus, there was somewhat of a need to increase the workforce that was out at the location. Also, there was a lot of in-fighting and quarrels that occurred. They were corrected as quickly as possible, but a lot of these hiring decisions should never had been made. Overall the system is great and I enjoyed my time there.

review_title: Laid back environment... and it shows.
job_title: in College Station, TX
pros: The environment is very laid back.  There are plenty of opportunities for professional advancement (though prof. development is iffy for budget reasons).  It's a much better place to work than Texas A&M, and it's easy to make the transition from one to the other.  Competency is recognized and rewarded, though incompetency tends to go un-punished.
cons:
Salaries are typically low as per educational environments.  Competencies are typically low as per government environments.  The IT department is an exception to both things, but you still have to deal with other departments...

The executives seem to be engaged more in a power struggle/blame game than in growing and developing the institution.  Unfortunately this trickles down to the entire institution, as they will occasionally demand your support in their turf wars.  There are plenty of people who have far too little work to do and plenty of time to gossip and politick.  Work directly for one of the colleges, don't work for the central administration.

job_title: Head Life Guard in College Station, TX
pros: Very flexible schedule, however it can be hard to find people to cover your shifts.  Pay is competitive for campus jobs and you have the ability to get a 20 cent raise every semester you work.  The Aquatics management is great.  They really care about you personally.  They are always willing to help you out no matter what.
cons: Scheduling can be quite awful sometimes.  It really just depends on the graduate assistant or whomever is doing the schedule.  It never follows a set list of guidelines.  For people who have worked there over 3 years, we should get our first preference on what we want to work and also how many weekends we work.  I just hate how equipment and some procedures are dysfunctional.  You really have to open to trying to new and just trying to make things work.  It can be frustrating.

job_title: Veterinarian in College Station, TX
pros: Working in academia provides flexibility
cons: A petty, non-collegial environment with no mentorship

review_title: Aggie jokes aren't jokes, but rather documentation
job_title: Systems Analyst in College Station, TX
pros: Being a state school, a certain amount of security exists.  Cost of living in town is very low.  Even though health insurance isn't what it was, it's still the best in town.  Good state mandated holidays.
cons: VERY topheavy management structure.  most are idiots that just shuffle papers back and forth to each other.  Faculty vs. staff situation creates second class feeling for staff, who do most of the work.  Very unfair benefits/perks structure.  Obvious favoritism in hirings and promotions.  President and upper university management totally out of touch with working class employees.  The university has a transparent policy of reducing actual pay by charging employees for many alleged "services" that should be provided gratis.  Very racist campus.  In spite of public talk of diversity, to them diversity  means Black Republicans, Asian Republicans, etc.

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros:
-Student worker jobs vary widely; some are much more easier than others, but in general they are limited to clerical work.
- Personally, I worked for a smaller Liberal Arts department; work was pretty easy (keeping printers loaded, making coffee, running errands for the department, preparing colloquia, etc.)
- Some elements of upper management very friendly.
- Very reasonable with schedule: worked around classes, got time off when I needed it.
- Often able to do classwork during slow times at work.
cons:
-Pay is pretty low--near minimum wage. Raises are rare. Other departments give more raises, though.
-Often, the highest levels of management are highly incompetent and their secretaries do the work they're assigned.
-Rarely knew of changes or news to the department. Made my job as the main office greeter a lot harder.
-While most of the professors are nice, many are clueless or are just plain rude.
-You're the lowest person on the totem pole. Not only do you have to take the blame for a lot of things, but you get the most inane and mindless work available.

review_title: Great experience if you're willing to work hard.
job_title: Graduate Assistant
pros:
Texas A&M University is well-known and a very competent university.  While it is large, graduate students won't be immersed in the 300 person-per-classroom type of atmosphere and instead will have small ~20 student classes.

Adviser's can be hit or miss, I had a good one so my feedback for poor or good performance was adequate and my work load and his understanding of personal life was also adequate.
cons: The school and most advisers do not provide enough "push" behind you to get done within the recommended 2 year period.  So, many graduate students will languish as long as they can and take 3 years to complete a degree that doesn't make them worlds more competitive.

review_title: Outstanding Researchers, with an excellent atmosphere and focus on education.
job_title: Student Worker in Amarillo, TX
pros:
Focused on your education
Excellent work-life balance
Fair compensation
Outstanding researchers who are down to earth and genuinely care about their research and employees
High standard of excellence
Always encouraging of employees endeavors
cons:
Top management often knows little to nothing about each individual researcher's efforts, and takes no time to try and understand before making decisions that will impact everyone.

It is a state agency that is subject to state budgetary concerns

Many people from the outside looking in see little to no value in what goes on, it needs to be 'marketed' better to the public because it can benefit everyone not just producers/farmers.

review_title: Nice people to work with. Flexible work schedule. Getting anything involving HR done takes a while
job_title: Technician II in Weslaco, TX
pros: Coworkers are really nice and easy to work with. The administration are nice enough people. I have a lot of freedom with what I work on. The office environment was clean and the bathrooms were well taken care of. I am satisfied with the work i do. I can tell the work I do is appreciated. While I was a student employee the work schedule was very flexible.
cons: Anything having to do with HR takes forever since I work in one of the satellite office in Texas and a lot of things need to get approved by someone in College Station. I just recently went from 'student worker' to full time employee.  Even as a full time employee I don't receive any benefits. Because I'm not a student anymore, my contract to work will only last for six months. At least that's what I was lead to believe.

job_title: Administrative Associate III in College Station, TX
pros: Opportunities to grow, holiday schedule, informed of interesting things happening on campus, most co-workers and faculty are supportive, lots of training opportunities, wellness initiative, benefits are great.
cons: A bit of a gamble as to how good or bad your bosses are. Threat of budget cuts every fiscal year that seem to only affect lower level employees. Often don't have time to take advantage of training opportunities to do the jobs thrust upon remaining people. Resources for large projects are often spread out or don't come to light until after the fact.

job_title: Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros:
A&M is a good university to work for because there are sooo many great minds in one place! You can learn a great diversity of things from a highly diverse group of people with varying areas of expertise. 

The library is also great! Access to every peer reviewed journal out there. And if an article isn't online, you can request it from the library and they'll email it to you in days.
cons: A&M is huge. There are people studying every subject, but they don't always work together because they don't know where to find each other, or they don't even though they exist. Collaboration can be difficult just due to the sheer size of the institution. There is also some bureaucracy to deal with when getting refunds for example.

review_title: Review of Student Position at Rudder Theater Complex, VERY Small Part of Overall University
job_title: Event Stage Hand- Student Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: In my subsection, it is a very open and mostly friendly atmosphere. Time-off and scheduling is very easy and they are very willing to work with student schedules. Job is pretty interesting, and there is a ton of variety (if you like that). For me, that means every day I might have a new task, and also this means I learned a lot of different things that I was not expecting to.
cons: While I only see a little of this, overall the University is extremely bureaucratic, and feels very disjointed at times. Sometimes the people can have a negative effect on your work experience but I think that applies anywhere. For my job specifically, it can be very hectic sometimes when there are a lot of things going on, and other days will be extremely slow.

review_title: Focused on research more than on student's education
job_title: Lecturer in College Station, TX
pros: There are many services for students as well as faculty improvement opportunities such as training and seminars free to lecturers. There is great school spirit & traditions and overall it isn't a party school but serious students and the largest Corps of Cadets in the U.S.  The small college town is nice after you get used to it. Larger cities are at least 2 hours away.
cons: The pay is too low for all the work. Teacher's needs for their classrooms and pay in this relatively high-rent town is disappointing. It is definitely full-time with committees and extra duties requested. Every decision by the university seems to be based on their income rather than on what is best for the student's personal development or for the lecturer's needs. Too much focus on research and those dedicating time to that instead of caring for classes..

review_title: Texas A&M's research facilities are great for starting off your career as a research assistant.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Texas A&M's research facilities are very-well equipped, and the faculty here are all experts in their field.  It is fairly easy to find your niche once you've spent about a year or so on this campus; there's a lot of culture for you to learn and traditions to take part in; every Aggie will help you feel at home here in College Station.
cons: The only downside in working at Texas A&M is having to deal with academic politics and the ever-evolving construction on campus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Lots of independence. Good chance to learn, interact with professors, and interact with undergraduate students. Most of the specific opportunities depend heavily on the research group one joins. There are opportunities for experimentation and modeling.
cons: Graduate school can require a lot of independent work. This is a pro and a con. The good part is that often times you can pursue ideas and take time to learn. It is a marathon not a sprint. Except the first year, which feels more like a sprint and is very competitive.

review_title: Comfortable place to work and raise a family
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: College Station is a great place to raise a family and A&M is a stable place to work.  The work/life balance is great.  Cost of living is cheap and there is little traffic.
cons: Not a lot of chances for advancement.  Once you reach a certain level, you are pretty much waiting for people to retire.  There was almost no budget for training in my department.  The little money we had was doled out based on seniority to people who had been there 20+ years.  Compensation is on the low end.  College Station is not a very exciting place to live if you are single and over 25 years old.

review_title: Good place to make friends via trial trough fire.
job_title: "Bookseller" in College Station, TX
pros:
Typically, the coworkers on the same level as you are cool people.  
Flexible schedule to work around college schedule.
Time off granted if in an emergency. 
No drug test to speak of.
cons:
Upon hiring, they say (or said to me) that I would receive a pay raise every 6 months, which didn't happen.  
Little chance of advancement, unless you want to become a manager after you graduate college (primarily a part-time job for college students).  
The management hate their job, and so make it a miserable place to work for everyone under them.  
Along those lines, employees are severely micromanaged.
They make it mandatory to work during the football games (a con for most college students -- especially Aggies).  
There are more, but I've not worked there for approximately a year, these are just the first things that come to mind.

job_title: Senior Office Associate in College Station, TX
pros: The people are friendly and upbeat, the university is in the middle of town and close to restaurants and the employees get to use the university library. They have started adding in free exercise classes to help employees overall health and wellbeing. Being in the TAMU community instills a sense of pride.
cons: Most of the actual tasks are very mundane and yet require critical accuracy. Files that you may never need to look at again or will become critically important without warning, forms that have to be proofread 10 times to make sure nothing is out of place, and notetaking on conference calls with 15 or so people all discussing projects that fall outside of your regular job involvement so the acronyms and shorthand references made on the call are confusing.

review_title: Experience with TAMU as a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in College Station, TX
pros: A lot of opportunity to get a position in oil and gas industry, people here are very friendly. There are a lot of opportunity to get funding for your study, for example, there are a lot of opportunity to work as a teaching assistant. Oil and gas company also provide a lot of support for fellowships. Your schedule could be very flexible. Professors are very friendly to students.
cons: There is not a strong atmosphere of research in our department, most of the students are preparing themselves for oil and gas industry. In fact, a lot of students have the opportunity to do internships or full time job in oil and gas companies. Every September to October, a lot of oil and gas company come for hiring new employee, therefore, you will feel interrupted for your research.

job_title: Student Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Most student employee positions allow for flexible hours to fit students' schedules. Student employees also can get early registration for classes. In working for a laboratory a student is able to learn a great deal about many different types of equipment and skills, which is convenient if you're working for the same field that you are studying. The network of Aggies throughout the state of Texas is good at securing jobs for graduates.
cons: Very few departments will allow student employees to work overtime hours in  order to pay off tuition, loans, rent, groceries, general bills that are a byproduct of attending a university.

review_title: Good pay, good opportunities, boring town...
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: I'm attending Texas A&M University to obtain my M.S. in Mechanical Engineering. The department here is quite prestigious, and it's a great place to perform research and study.  I'm also employed by the department via research assistant ship. The pay and benefits are both pretty good for a student.
cons: This city has no culture (aside from that which is derived from the athletics department...) and only a sparse amount of entertainment (mainly Northgate and downtown Bryan). It's very conducive to being a student but not so much for being a person. Also, in general, the faculty tends to work grad students extremely hard, sometimes as much as 50+ hours per week (which is considered overtime in the real world).

review_title: Sad that in a place with so much potential, leadership is so mediocre
job_title: Research Associate in College Station, TX
pros: Resource availability, quality of the junior faculty, work environment, students.
cons: The worst leadership I've seen. From the current president to deans and department heads. Some of the senior faculty should have also retired long ago. These people will make sure that nothing that threatens their mediocre performance can opaque their artificial light. The university authorities play this game by showcasing these dinosaurs as the images of the institution. All of this is pathetic and will scare away anyone who has a brain inside the skull and can find a reasonable good job somewhere else.

review_title: If you're a student it's a good place to work, varies a lot by department/college though
job_title: Student Technician in College Station, TX
pros:
I'm a student here, so working on campus is very convenient. 

Decent pay for student workers. 

The department I work for is nice and gives me a flexible schedule so I can take off when I need to do some extra studying for a test or something. 

People are usually pretty nice here.
cons:
Office politics, managers don't listen to employees. 

I know for full time employees, advancement and promotion are very limited. The school usually likes to hire outside people for management (rather than promoting from within)

Some of the conservative culture here can be off putting, but that's mostly because it's Texas I guess.

review_title: Long term employee, just couldn't get promoted.
job_title: Trainer in College Station, TX
pros:
Great to be associated with a major university. I felt that I was helping educate the citizens of the state of Texas. So when my career eneded, I felt that I had accomplished something with my life. 
They do provide professional development for their employees.You get to work with some truly outstanding and amazingly talented people.
cons: The whole organization functions like a feudal kingdom. The President is king, the management are royalty, professors are knights, and employees are serfs. Many feel "stuck" in boring jobs, which they can't escape from. Just about every employee is over-qualified for the position they are in. When its your time to go, they will not hesitate to banish you from the kingdom.

job_title: Graduate Student in College Station, TX
pros: For research in agriculture this is a top University and provides an opportunity to be involved in cutting edge work.
cons: The location of the University in a small town can make it difficult to find work for a spouse or to have a life outside of the University.

job_title: Graduate Assistant
pros: What can I say, we're a top 25 school in Chemistry, stipend is competitive, it's actually pretty good when you consider the cost of living in the area.  The department as a whole is very good, lots of interaction between the groups, inside and outside of the laboratory.  The University has a need for more and better research support facilities, but they have improved markedly since my arrival and it appears that they will continue to do so.  All in all, you could do much worse.
cons: Some of the laboratories in the older buildings need to be completely redone, Chemistry as a whole needs more space than what is currently allotted.

review_title: Politics dominate at the top, skilled and motivated staff at lower levels penalized for contributing vs butt kissing
job_title: in College Station, TX
pros: Extensive resources to do research and development, high-speed computing;
cons:
Managerial positions are filled by appointees who usually are good at butt-kissing and climbing; not all middle managers are like that but in general the higher the position the more political backing was invested to push the appointee there. Usually skilled and intelligent employes whose motive is to contribute are pushed aside and their contributions hidden by higher management. 
There is NO evaluation of middle managers and with this lack of negative feedback situation deteriorates continuously.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Texas A&M University is a top tier research institution. The engineering programs provide excellent education and the Aggie identity and traditions makes us a collaborative community with a strong former students network.
cons: Some people do not like College Station because it is a small college town, however there are other cities nearby that can provide variety of entertainment options such as Hoston, Austin and San Antonio.

job_title: Research Technician in Lubbock, TX
pros: very interesting research, lots of new things to learn, mostly pleasant staff, flexible hours, excellent policies for sick leave, overtime, and vacation time. Each person in charge of their area was always very professional and capable.
cons: LONG HOURS during certain parts of the season, some programs are serially understaffed, bad office politics on occasion, pay is pretty low relative to local standards, some out of date research methods and low initiative to upgrade equipment, difficulty in communicating/coordinated with agricultural partners. Some hostility and intimidation with the older crowd. There were several incidents with a long-term staff member that went unreported due to fear of backlash.

review_title: An organization more than a company
job_title: Facilities Staff in College Station, TX
pros: Your peers are fellow students who become some of your best friends. You work day in and day out with each other and really get to know each other and best close, the best time to work is over the summer when the employee staff is smaller so that you get to know each other a lot faster and its easier to get promoted.
cons: The promotion process is a little political and you kind of have to suck up to get promoted. The pay is not very well either, but it is a part time college job so you go into it knowing you won't get paid a lot.

review_title: OK if they are paying your tuition.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: It is on campus so you don' t have to commute if you are a grad student. Also, it is a good way to get familiar with how courses at A&M work.
cons: One of the major downsides is that you have to reapply every semester. At the end of each semester, you may be terminated without notice. I found out by my insurance company telling me I was no longer a customer. Also, I wasn't notified that I was a TA, I just happened to get a TA memo with my name on it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: The cost of living in College Station is quite low and even with a meager graduate assistant salary, you can live in relative comfort. The university and atmosphere is very friendly and its rare to find rude people.
cons: The city again is too "religious" and conservative. It is not reflective in the university. However, you will find more than a 5-6 religious institutions in any given neighborhood. I also find it a little closed minded compared to places like austin

review_title: There's a Spirit can never be told...
job_title: University Ambassador in College Station, TX
pros: The spirit and pride of the place makes it one of the best places to work for. If you have a desire to serve something larger than yourself this would be a great place for you to work. Also, the students here are some of the best in the nation, all are considerate for the most part.
cons: The bureaucracy. It takes a lot to get very little done. While some of this is necessary much of it is simply there to be there. It often times takes one or two phone calls more than it should, just to get the number for the correct place, much lessthe actual answer that you are searching for.

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: I was at the Winemiller Aquatic Ecology Lab as a student worker. The main pro was the flexible work schedule. You get to come into the lab on campus when your schedule allows. They would give me steady raises as I worked their for a year. I started at $8.50 and ended at $10/hr. The supervisors are very dedicated to helping you solve problems with data and they care about you learning new things.
cons: Some of the downsides are that there isn't room for growth, the supervisors are working on their masters and PhD degrees. Working in a laboratory is also tedious and you don't get any human interaction besides working with a co-worker occasionally.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kingsville, TX
pros:
My professor was very professional and helpful. He got me Dean's scholarship as well.
If employed for 20 hours per week, then automatically instate tuition fee waiver is applicable. But it depends on the professor and his funding. My Professor was reach with his funding.
cons:
The orientation is very length although it is online.
The benefits, especially the health insurance is is applicable only after 2 months of service and if for some reason, the employment has a break which is usual due to holiday period, then the 2 month waiting period appears again. I hardly ever benefitted from the University's Employee Health Plan.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: the university has a strong background in research and it is well connected to industry, especially the energy sector in Texas. The departments tend to be large so there are plenty of different areas of research to pick from.
cons: The university is located in a rather small urban area, the College Station/Bryan area. So living there is not that exciting. The bureaucracy at Texas A&M can be difficult to deal with at times. Mainly because different areas overlap.

review_title: Overall TAMU is a decent place to work with a great culture and friendly employees.
job_title: Human Resources Analyst in College Station, TX
pros: Professional development is valued.  Great state retirement plan.  Some departments offer a flexible work schedule.  Depending on the department you work in, the pay can be pretty decent.  Strong management in certain departments.
cons: Lots of red tape.  Outsourcing.  Layoffs.  Constant organizational changes in HR - a result of money wasted every few years on useless consultants.  Weak management in some areas, as in every company.  Not a lot of promotional/advancement opportunities.  Merit increases are few and far between.

review_title: Great Involvment, Flexible work schedules, too much beureacracy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kingsville, TX
pros: Great involvement on campus, the U tries really hard to make sure students have a voice and part in the institution. And staff is very understanding that school comes before a job.
cons: There was just too much red tape and unprofessional attitudes in the mid-lower management level, the systems at those levels regardless of dept. or office seemed to be build on friendships or some other kind of socal or relationship based benifits - altogether unprofessional, unbusinesslike, and very 'i'll scratch yours, if you scratch mine'...

job_title: Marketing Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: I worked as a student in the marketing department and was able to gain so much hands on experience in all things marketing and communications. I was given lots of tasks and responsibilities that taught me valuable marketing skills and my supervisor always made sure I was learning and understanding the processes. The management team is excellent and it is easy to tell that the whole staff really values the work that students do.  They worked out a program where I could stay on after I graduated and have been very supportive as I search for a full-time role.
cons: Since the marketing department is small, there is not much room for advancement within the department. Other than that, no complaints!

job_title: Seeking Professional Job in San Jose, CA
pros: Great HR, and assistance with tax filling, biweekly pay, good working environment. Overall was a great experience to be employed and allowed to work on my our research at the same time.
cons: Obviously not a full-time job salary, no benefits or paid sick days. However, the salary compensated greatly to the low stipend obtained as an international student. Long hours, lots of projects. Have to work with people with total lack of knowledge thus had to train them while doing my job.

review_title: Great place to work, terribly underpaid
job_title: Tour Guide in College Station, TX
pros:
Flexibility of Hours and the ability to work around class schedules.  The work is fun and exciting and you get to meet new people every day.  If you have a test coming up, you're usually able to spend your time studying while at the computer.

You really have  to have a passion for the University to do well but the employees are friendly and its a really laid back atmosphere.
cons: Software is outdated and often times there are too many people working at one time which means there is constant downtime.  Management is simply terrible and so is the pay.  Minimum wage... seriously????

review_title: Great place to do some applicable research
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: TAMU provides a good research environment in terms of facilities and resources. The town of college Station as a whole is laid back and provides a stress free environment to relax and focus on ones research. There has also been more emphasis on interdisciplinary research, forging collaborations between different departments and faculties, which raises the quality of research being done here.
cons:
More of the money seems to be getting diverted towards sporting - football in particular, attracting commercial interests on campus.
Parking permit prices keep going up, while the number of parking places are dwindling due to all the new constructions.

review_title: Good research for highly motivated, independent students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Excellent opportunities for research and good facilities (depending on the field).   I was able to do some novel multidisciplinary research and collaborative with other labs outside of my department.  Salary is above average
cons: Researchers are very knowledgeable in their field but can be terrible in the classroom (I had a mix of really good and really bad profs during my coursework).  Living in College Station is less than desirable to say the least.  School resources can be lacking in you are not in an engineering program or an undergrad

job_title: Graduate Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Texas A&M has a great reputation  - especially if you remain in the state of Texas.  Most of the professors really do care about the individual student.
cons: As a graduate student, you are expected to work and work and work for very little pay as well as terrible benefits (health insurance and otherwise).  $1600 (gross) a month is not much at all.  Basically, you are considered a student when it benefits the university and an employee when it benefits the university.  One piece of advice - get everything you are promised in writing.

job_title: Senior Lead Software Applications Developer in College Station, TX
pros:
- Laid back work environment
- Low stress
- Great vacation & sick leave policies
- College Station is a great town to raise a family with cheap housing and an awesome community
cons:
- Faculty like to build small empires which can be problematic to deal with.
- Low pay for professional staff. The same position in Austin at UT will typically have a %30 higher pay rate while the cost of living for both cities are almost the same.
- You can not advance your career unless you move between departments within the university.

review_title: Great place to work. Nice people, nice organization, but what exactly does "AgriLife" do??
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: The organization has a familial feel. It seems like many employees stay there for quite some time, but there is also always new people (eg. graduate students, professors, research assistants) coming on board through the University. Overall, good benefits, and College Station based employees can enjoy being a part of a well-resourced public university.
cons: There seems to be no limits as to what "AgriLife" does. Feels a bit like mission creep. Staff are too homogeneous - ie. they love anything and everything Aggieland, generally Caucasian, conservative, and from rural Texas.

review_title: Great place to learn and work, highly collaborative research environment
job_title: Graduate Student in College Station, TX
pros: The best thing about scientific research at Texas A&M is the collaborative environment. As a graduate student this makes scientific research exciting and provides different avenues of research to pursue, especially with leading researchers in every field.
cons: I come from a busy city, so the biggest con for me is the location. The city itself on the smaller side, although it is growing rapidly with lots of university development. However, outside of College Station, it takes a couple hours to reach a big city like Houston or Dallas, if that's something you're going to miss. This might be a plus for some people who don't want too many distractions.

job_title: Software Development Manager in College Station, TX
pros: The A&M System is by far the best employer in College Station. For full-time employees benefits are good and there is opportunity to advance in many professions and do interesting work. System is in good financial health and is conservatively managed.
cons: In general, salaries in College Station are significantly lower than in larger cities. At times A&M can be overly bureaucratic and driven by compliance rather than common sense. Leadership doesn't always value staff contributions to their success. Faculty and research prima donnas wag the dog at times.

job_title: Senior Student in College Station, TX
pros:
Living on campus is one of the best ways to get a sense of community and to make friends. 
There are many great professors and courses offered here, but you gotta do your research on who is great and who is terrible.
cons:
There is not much diversity here, but there are several organizations that help you connect with other people like you, for example, Mexican Student Organization, Comic Club, LGBTQ organization, etc. 
Freshman 15 is real, you will gain weight if you don't exercise every day. (plus you pay hundreds for your membership in the Rec, get the most out of your money)

job_title: Student Bus Driver in College Station, TX
pros: The pay is reasonable. They just started fixing the problems with it when I left. The supervisors are generally pretty cool, and driving buses is a fun way to meet people. If you stay out of the office, it's great.
cons: The managers above the supervisors don't have a clue how to run things. It's not uncommon to hear the phrase "Why didn't we just do that instead? Oh wait, because that would make sense." The punishments don't fit the crime when you make a mistake. There's a lot of drama in the office.

review_title: As a student worker, it's a really good experience and opportunity to gain valuable skills for later jobs.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: Most employers are flexible with your schedule if you're still a student. You can gain skills and titles for future jobs.
cons: Watch out for favoritism, as with practically any job. Also, still not a fully integrated or diverse school/work place so if you're minority, be prepared for the tension since most bosses are stuck with old mentality, but this depends where you work in A&M but there are more of them around. Also, don't expect for a high pay since A&M doesn't have much money so you can be prepared for $7.50-$9 and definitely no benefits working as a student worker.

job_title: Student Worker in Bryan, TX
pros: They sometimes give you food.
cons: DO NOT work here if you are a student. Your pay will be capped at $10 per hour and 28 hours per week. They will not let you work more because they don't want to give you benefits. They are trying to ( and succeeding) in phasing all the men out of the Deans Office. You will be taken advantage of being a student worker here. No time to study and extremely inconvenient to get to from main campus. No parking passes. The closest one is a mile away and good luck getting it. If you complain about what you are doing and the work environment( no matter what's happening), they will just fire you and hire another student. DO NOT WORK HERE.

review_title: TAMU is good and getting better
job_title: Research Scientist in College Station, TX
pros: Great location between Houston, Dallas, and Austin when you want to get out of town.  Downtown Bryan is also pretty cool.  Housing is extremely affordable to buy or rent.
cons: The University is growing like crazy so traffic, is getting worse by the day.  Not many major negatives that I can think of - I mean it's not New York City, but there's enough to make it interesting.  There's definitely a politically conservative vibe here (and throughout this red state) so flaming liberals beware. :)

job_title: Human Resources Generalist II in Kingsville, TX
pros: I loved to meet new employees and assist them day to day with the benefits, retirement, and absence roles I played.
cons: The management in HR went down hill. If he didn't like you, he wouldn't help you. There was a lot of nepotism going on, people who weren't qualified were getting promoted and hired. They do not pay according to your job duties and experience, it is more about who you are and if you are liked.

job_title: Landscape Supervisor in College Station, TX
pros: The Retirement benefits are great, better than 401k. You feel part of the Aggie family. The City of College Station is a wonderful place to live with excellent schools. Very family oriented.
cons: The University is making drastic budget cuts. There are stories throughout campus(both facilities and academia) regarding the withholding of raises and sometimes breeching of contracts, due to the universities financial situation. The chancellor of the university has recently outsourced all facilities including, landscape, dinning, maitenance and housekeeping. Some have suggested that they have also been looking to outsource the IT department as well.

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: At Texas A&M it is easy to develop great relationships with staff and faculty. The university's atmosphere is unmistakeably unique and rooted in integrity. Supervisors are always willing to help with school schedule/extracurriculars.
cons: The university it quite large, so there is no way you will ever meet everyone. Sometimes this can be hard when communicating with people in different departments, but generally people are very helpful.

job_title: Lecturer in College Station, TX
pros: There are so many great things at A&M. Living and working environment, resources, infrastructure, potential and opportunities, weather, etc.
cons: Very poor leadership. I mean, seriously limited people stuck in high rank academic administrative positions who will ensure no one brights too much. No push for innovative initiatives.  Everyone is comfy where they are doing as little as they can.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in College Station, TX
pros:
- Decent starting benefits and stipend pay.
- Good pay (relative to the rest of the country)
cons:
- Classes taught completely depends on the department you are in.
- If your advisor doesn't have any grants there is no guarantee you will be paid (but you would know that ahead of time)
- Number of hours worked is completely arbitrary and depends on work group
- Fees are not necessarily covered by advisor
- You might be here for decades and leave without a degree. :-(

job_title: Communications Coordinator in College Station, TX
pros: Very dynamic and large-scale place to work and get experience during early and mid-level parts of your career. In my time, I have gained the opportunity to be promoted twice in 3.5 years, and collaborate with students, faculty, staff, and high-level administrators on a variety of internationally-focused projects.
cons:
Difficult to get into upper-level management. High burn out rate, due to work and time demands. 
Highly decentralized since it is a large campus, which means collaborating with different colleges and departments often show inconsistencies and organizational flow holes.

job_title: Graduate Student in College Station, TX
pros:
- Very experienced faculty
- Growing young faculty with diversified interests, highly collaborative
- Fantastic emphasis on widely applicable and professional ready skills.
- Good networking and support
cons:
- Divisions between faculty and administration obvious
- Inconsistent adherence to process, moving more and more to personality-driven management and decisions rather than measurable process driven ones.
- Grad student funding highly dependent on professor funding availability

review_title: My experience here will be short and sweet because as soon as I got here I began looking for other jobs.
job_title: Grad Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: A very conservative group and for academics that's rare so the balance is nice. I would leave in a heartbeat if there was anything else offered.
cons: The school school itself is ALL about the money, they wont repair trivial things such as water fountains or change light bulbs but have no issues with charging 300+ each semester for parking.

job_title: Library Specialist III in College Station, TX
pros:
-Large research library with a great collection.
-Interacting with students who want to use the library and are excited when they discover the services the library offers.
cons:
-Conservative environment.
-There is a major fear and aversion to change. 
-Working as a staff member is very unrewarding, many of the faculty members treat staff as second class and staff work is often unrecognized or the credit taken by the supervisor.

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: The faculty are very courteous, understanding of student schedules, and provide a great workplace environment. Being at a University, they are very mindful if you are a full-time student and don't mind if you work on schoolwork during downtime.
cons: There are not any particular downsides to a position as a student worker, aside from the obvious cons that are characteristic of the position. Such features include no advancement or increase in pay that you might see in a job outside of a student worker position.

job_title: Undergraduate Researcher in College Station, TX
pros: Working at Texas A&M as a student researcher (undergraduate) over the summer was a lot of fun. I learned a lot about electromagnetics and antenna engineering, two fields a knew very little about prior to doing research, and the work environment was very relaxed.
cons: The pay wasn't the best working as an undergraduate. Although I was paid $10/hr, I was limited to 10 paid hours per week, and I often worked more hours to feel like a good team member, as most of the other undergraduates worked extra hours as well.

review_title: Solid teaching assistant position with a good department
job_title: Technology Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: I worked as a "technology teaching assistant" in the statistics department, which meant I provided some technical support to the online master's program.  I generally worked no more than 10 hours a week and was paid well.  All the things I needed to know I was taught, and the environment was pretty low key.  My supervisor was awesome and super easy to work for.
cons: I had a hard time as a PhD student; I decided to leave with a masters.  Working as a technology teaching assistant didn't give me opportunities to further my stats skills or get experience teaching.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros:
Very helpful advisor
Relatively high pay rate
I was able to work as best suited me
Exposure to a lot of new material and a lot of potential to learn
cons:
Lost funding for my project quickly and have been unemployed since
Not a friendly professional environment for most people other than healthy white males, especially women
Some departments take advantage of foreign students and overwork them without compensation
Education was far inferior compared to what I expected, I observed cheating going without consequence

job_title: Communications Specialist in College Station, TX
pros: Good environment, nice people. College Station is a nice area to live in, and the campus community is top notch. If you can stand the heat of a Texas summer I would recommend working for Texas A&M University.
cons:
Promoting faculty to staff managerial positions puts them above staff members who have more experience in their field than the faculty member. 
The state of Texas seems to view higher education as a barely necessary evil and as such every legislative session is filled with budget cuts and talk of "excess waste".

job_title: Sarikum Golu/Hydrogeological Researcher in College Station, TX
pros: Working at the University gave me the opportunity to learn additional skills while attending classes, plus I was able to put something on my resume, which meant I was employed within one month of graduation.
cons: When you are an intern or an undergraduate assistant, you are on your own. Professors do not have time to micro-manage you so you should know what you are doing and be confident making decisions on your own. I had to work many hours alone in the lab, which was isolating, but over all it was a very positive experience.

review_title: It was very fulfilling, mentor was caring as well as on top of the work.
job_title: Undergraduate Researcher in College Station, TX
pros: There is a sense of belonging there.  It is one big Aggie family.  The professors are very helpful.  Texas A&M being a big school in a small city has it's benefits too.
cons: It is a very small town and sometimes can be a problem to get promoted to the next level.  Many times bigger things are in bigger cities.

job_title: IT Professional in College Station, TX
pros: Nice campus, unlimited challenges, opportunities to help students and research. Massive changes are likely coming to knock down the silos, consolidate, and be more "commercial".
cons: Pay scale is way off, even when considering cost of living. HR has been protecting low performing staff.

review_title: Great place to start a career.
job_title: Academic Advisor II in College Station, TX
pros: The family like atmosphere and different opportunities are great. The campus community and students are great.  The university has a vision and strong values.  The surrounding area is great for families.
cons: Low pay, the only way to move up is to find a new position.  Employees do not fee valued at times and everything is pushed down on advisors who are treated like assistants.

job_title: Graduate Assistant
pros: Working at Texas A&M. The people. The culture. Getting access to the online databases for journal articles. Winter is a beautiful time of year when you can wear sweatshirts and sweaters and long sleeves and not get hot.
cons: The undergrads. They are everywhere. traffic. when the students are in town a 13 min commute can turn into 30-40 min. The summer is oppressively hot. its in the 100s from june-early october.

job_title: Student Worker II in College Station, TX
pros: Working as a student worker at Texas A&M has been a great experience. My co-workers exemplify the spirit of Aggieland. They are fun to get along with, and unlike common knowledge there is a very diverse group of people that work with me on a day to day basis. We respect each other. Going to work is not a drag. People help each other out.
cons: Some people say the system is micro-managed. Processing times are abhorrent (management is slow)

job_title: Graduate Assistant Teaching in College Station, TX
pros: Texas A&M clearly puts effort to provide assistance for most students, rather than just for some. The teaching assistantship is challenging, but rewarding. Flexible in terms of time required, and granted a great deal of autonomy in decision making on day-to-day activities.
cons: Training is insufficient, and hardly even exists. No feedback offered by supervisors or provided by students unless solicited. Monthly pay, as is typical for positions like this.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Texas A&M University is the professionalism, respect, and mutual bonding/friendship due to the university. I have felt supported in all of the different jobs I have had here, and have met some inspiring professionals.
cons: The only downside would be if you are from UT or a large city, then the adjustment might not be as smooth. However, if you are looking for a city with great schools and a high quality of life, then College Station could be the perfect fit.

review_title: A good place to retire to
job_title: Research Engineer in College Station, TX
pros: Overall, this is a typical college town. Good neighborhood, safe, relaxed life style, little traffic. A&M is the biggest employer in the area and the campus is fast growing and so does the town. There are always a lot going on on campus and you will find a lot to do if you have a young heart. Football season is crazy and all exciting.
cons: The Aggies has overly conservative traditions and the university is not in a prime location. As such, the university is hard to get into the top notch ranking category despite of its impressive research and degree programs.

review_title: Decent place to work for to help pay for school.
job_title: Information Security Officer in College Station, TX
pros:
Tuition paid
Helps to pay for school, generally flexible schedule
Telecommuting is almost always a possibility.
cons: Incompetent managers and peers.  Working for faculty members is extremely frustrating most of the time.  Most of the time as long as nothign is broken in your department, no other effort is spent to make sure that everything else is fine.  As a result of this, very little progress is made in general.  Also, promotions are nearly impossible to come by and the benefits package is not great.

review_title: A great place to hone skills.
job_title: Graphic Designer in College Station, TX
pros: Good work/life balance; opportunities for training; great coworkers. Great retirement benfits and adequate insurance. Opportunities for personal and career growth abound. If you're willing to put in the effort to become a SME, you can be a rockstar.
cons: Low pay, at least initially. They're the main gig in town, they know it and they pay like it. Merit raises come slowly. You really need to distinguish yourself (and often times know the right people) to advance your career.

job_title: Graduate Student in College Station, TX
pros:
1. One of famous University in Engineering. Students are hardworking and excellent. Companys like graduated students from this university.
2. Cheap and save money for expense.
3. Texas is a good state for working. From a&m, it is easier to find a job at texas.
cons:
1. No so much opportunity from CA comparing to univeristy at CA. 
2. Not the best university in America.
3. The weather is hot and little dry here.

job_title: Jaguar Ambassador in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great higher education environment. An awesome cultural environment with people that actually care about the students and their post-graduation plan. Good university president that invests a lot of time into making the university great.
cons: University is still fairly new so events and systems can seem disorganized. Traditions are still being put in place. Planning from certain departments needs work when it comes to execution.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in College Station, TX
pros: Positive atmosphere and beautiful campus.
cons: While working at Texas A&M, there was a lack of transparency and honesty about shameful animal laboratory practices taking place inside Prof. Joe Kornegay's research lab, where he breeds golden retrievers to develop muscular dystrophy.  Many of these dogs die while they are puppies, and those who don't die live their miserable lives in a cage where they are subjected to more breeding and painful procedures.  When employees and students question administration, they are met with silence.  These secretive research practices with dogs are a stain on our great university's reputation, and they need to stop.

job_title: in College Station, TX
pros:
early registration (if a student), easy, independent atmosphere.

I worked in the lab at Blocker and put a lot of time in.  Pay isn't too great but then again you can study there, and getting paid to study is better than studying for free
cons: The cons were that since there was little supervision, my bosses never saw that I was actively helping customers and was knowledgeable about solutions (unlike most of my co-workers)

review_title: Great student position in a highly-respected office
job_title: Student Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: The office has many student assistants in all departments, so that means flexible schedules. You get to work with the public, which includes current and former students. You hear so many awesome stories and get to give Aggies their most cherished item! I loved getting to learn more about the Rings and have a hand in getting them to students.
cons: This is a student position, so there's not room to advance. Also, that means pay is minimum wage. Since Ring season is very busy, you are responsible for working into student holidays and over the summer.

review_title: Fun, a lot of projects came our way with little time in between but it was worth it in the long run.
job_title: Viz Student in College Station, TX
pros: A lot of individual growth as well as learning how to work well in a team. Very helpful instructors throughout the entirety of each project.
cons: A lot of instructors weren't well versed in the programs that were used for certain projects. A lot of "do your own research" mandates to get simple instruction for certain projects.

review_title: Good place to work for Students
job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: The pay is ok, hours must be negotiable for students. My boss at EHS always has things that need to get done, which is good at times and bad at times
cons: My boss always has things for me to do, which is sometimes too much. My hours are "capped" at 15hrs per week, which is annoying when I have the time to work and can use the money

job_title: Office Assistant--Temporary in College Station, TX
pros: Although I worked at A&M for only 6 months, I was very impressed by my supervisor and her guidance to each of the employees in our unit.  Each Monday morning we would have a team meeting.  At the beginning of the time, the director would review the previous week's events, offer praise to the participating employees, and open the discussion for ways to improve.  We would then look toward the coming week's events.  During this time each of us would say what we were working on, what our deadlines were, and if we needed assistance.  Although this was quite a sacrifice to everyone's schedule as the week was ramping up, it caused me to feel that I was an important part of the team, that I was never "in" any particular situation by myself, and that it mattered how things were carried out.  In addition, the director was careful to always stay positive about the department as a whole and never "bad-mouthed" her boss to us.  She acted as an umbrella to us, shielding us from the stress and intensity that she often felt.  I am so thankful that I was able to work for a person like her.
cons: I think that my experience was probably the exception to the rule.  I was told that because we were not an academic unit, we did not run into a lot of the politics that other units have to deal with.  The downside to that was that our resources were always extremely limited.  But given the way I was treated, I think it was worth it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: Good experience to learn how to deliver classes, manage students. Also, you reinforce your knowledge in the teaching class. With this part-time job grad student get a "in-state" rate for tuition,s and also a assistant ship discount.
cons:
If your professor don't cover your tuition (not my case), the money you have left (after paying your tuition and fees) is not enough to cover all your expenses (room, food, etc). Ask what are the policies in the department you are admitted.
Need to organize your time to prepare your classes, grade quizzes, homework and ALL YOUR STAFF (own classes, research etc)

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: The department I worked for while attending Texas A&M was absolutely amazing. The work I did each day was incredibly fulfilling, and went a long way in making our campus a more diverse and inclusive space, especially for international students. I also enjoyed a very flexible schedule, good compensation, and a lot of support from my immediate supervisors.
cons: The particular department for which I used to work was closed due to a lack of support from the University. In my opinion this was a mistake on the administration's part which consistently undervalued our department's work.

review_title: Great Total Benefits, But Ends There
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: The benefits of working for TAMU are great. You get a healthy about of sick leave and PTO with flexibility saving days. Pay is okay for the area.  Health insurance is great.
cons: Limited bonuses/raises and the 401k plan is embarrassing.

review_title: A wonderful place to work with the most friendly superiors
job_title: Graduate Assistant in College Station, TX
pros:
1. Friendly and supportive superiors
2. Minimum stress
3. Motivating compensation package
4. A wonderful supportive staff
5. Well knit network creating a conducive environment of work
6. Small and peaceful city of College Station / Bryan away from the busy city life
cons:
1. Very slow promotion ladder
2. Rigid structure
3. Small city of College Station sometimes bores the hell out of you if you have time to kill but nothing to do in this small town.

review_title: I enjoy working for Texas A&M University
job_title: Research Assistant in Galveston, TX
pros: TAMUG is a smaller campus which gives a nice sense of community. The campus is kept up well and there are many amenities.
cons: On the other side, because it is a smaller campus you do not have easy access to all the amenities offered on the main campus in College Station

review_title: Great or awful...depends on your unit and supervisor
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: A&M can be a great place to work; it just depends on which office or department you work for and the tone your immediate supervisor sets for the work environment. I've had great experiences working at the Writing Center and at the Bush School. Dr. Valerie Balester (Director of the Writing Center) and Amb. Ryan Crocker (Dean of the Bush School) epitomize what it means to be a good boss - lead by example, respect and appreciate your staff, and treat everyone fairly. Colleagues were respectful and respected, encouraged to grow and pursue professional development opportunities, and there was a genuine sense of team and belonging at both offices.
cons: A&M, like many large organizations subject to bureaucratic oversight and policies, is sometimes crippled in addressing problems in the workplace in a timely manner. Supervisors, particularly those with tenure, are often allowed to bully, harass, exploit, disrespect, and abuse subordinate staff, sometimes for years and despite repeated complaints being filed. While there are resources available to address complaints, the process is time consuming (which compounds the problem in a hostile environment) and often the employee is either expected to kowtow to unreasonable demands and behavior or transfer out of or resign from an intolerable situation (which allows the problem to persist and adversely affect other employees). When a conflict exists between a staff member and a faculty supervisor, the ineffectiveness is extreme since Employee Relations' hands are essentially tied when it comes to addressing faculty members' abusive behavior. Supervisors with a history of complaints are allowed to continue largely unchecked as long as the employees are willing to accept a transfer or resign. Employees are often encouraged to try to resolve the problem themselves and are advised to try speaking with abusive supervisors who have threatened them since HR  cannot intervene on an employee's behalf when the conflict is with a faculty member. Dean of Faculties is willing to listen to complaints, but requires an inordinate amount of time to take action and can only encourage affected employees to "wait and see" for indefinite amounts of time in increasingly-hostile work environments while sustaining additional abuse at the hands of faulty supervisors.

review_title: Great environment, good benefits, low pay
job_title: Applications Security Engineer in College Station, TX
pros: Texas A&M has a great overall atmosphere.  While it is the largest university in Texas, it often has the community feel of a small college.  I have great bosses and coworkers, and the benefits (healthcare, Texas Teacher Retirement System, etc) are good.
cons: The pay, for most staff, is low.  It is certainly below average for most industries.  A similar job at any nearby major city would probably fetch at least a 30 to 50% pay increase.

review_title: Great place to work for a student!
job_title: Student Driver in College Station, TX
pros: Working as a student bus driver for A&M's transportation services department was a solid job. The schedule was set from the the beginning of the semester, so it was easy to plan around. Management was extremely nice and professional, and the pay was pretty good for a student job.
cons:
Very early mornings or late nights are to be expected, especially for new drivers who create their schedule last.
Students are also expected to work a few gamedays, though they do accomodate workers by allowing them time off for the second/third quarter.

review_title: Fulfilling yet a lot of work for average pay
job_title: Assistant Director in College Station, TX
pros: Culture, values, staff. A lot of good people here. There is a lot of team work in my department, at least.
cons: Pay/benefits - just not very competitive. There is a bit of climate since 2008 with economic downturn that you just have to deal with it. The Provost's attitude certainly doesn't help to dispel this since she mentions it in almost every speech to staff.

job_title: IT Consultant in College Station, TX
pros:
Excellent work environment
Friendly and supportive Senior Support Staff
Focus on quality service instead of quantity of service
Very flexible hours for students
Excellent resume builder
Applicable skills for future careers
cons:
Hiring is slow, meaning Help Desk Central is never fully staffed
Some issues with upper management

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: Wonderful campus, Flexible hours, decent class sizes. I was able to assist on online courses which made it easy to manage responsibilities on campus and at home.
cons: Not a very diverse campus.  Supervising professor capability is a toss up, but that probably goes for most places. Some professors want you to teach a class for them and some are much more involved with the mentorship process.

job_title: Student Driver in College Station, TX
pros:
-Flexible Schedule
-Supervisors are easy to work with
-Almost always work available if you want it
-Work can be relaxing if you get into it and have thick skin
-One of few part time jobs in the B/CS area that pay more than min. wage (~$10/hr)
-Policies are necessarily harsh, but forgiveness is usually the M/O if you approach the hiring staff with an issue and have a good record.
cons:
This is titled: "Part time job", and that's all it is. Keep your head down, stay out of lines of fire, get paid. If you are looking for anything more than a little cash while you are a Texas A&M student- a place to grow, learn, thrive, or otherwise have a positive experience- you will walk away empty-handed. Except for a bit of cash, of course. 

-Unforgiving policies (that are rightfully in place) don't always give leeway when it is deserved

-Pay raises are dirt, and rarely are bonuses offered for needed work. 

-Callous and almost hostile atmosphere at times

-All levels of authority from dispatch to Director are inept, hostile, and continually frustrated. Best to stay out of their line of sight at all times. You will do well to just keep your head down and mouth shut.

-A culture of 'I alone know everything, you are an idiot' trickles down from the highest levels

-Department is poorly funded for its needs. Imagine if an equipment-heavy branch of the military like the Air Force was funded by giving them 75% of their costs incurred by equipment maintenance alone. They would use half of it on machinery, cut a lot of corners to make ends meet, and try to scrape by with the rest in all other areas. That's what Texas A&M does to Transit.

job_title: Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: If you are an undergrad and can't find an internship at another company, consider doing research for one of your professors. If you already have the maximum research credit, they will put you on payroll. It's a great place to start off if you are not sure where to start any internship or work experience.
cons: Your experience will very much depend on the grad student or professor you decide to work for. Its important to find someone who will be looking to help you gain experience and better your career for future employment.

review_title: Great compromise between small town and big city life
job_title: IT Manager in College Station, TX
pros: Overall great atmosphere, people are mostly extraordinarily friendly.  Departments prefer to promote from within whenever possible, and the personnel development is fantastic.  Being tied to the university culture is invigorating.
cons: Current chancellor seems to prefer outsourcing services instead of developing internally--university setting overall seems to be focusing more on generating revenue than quality of education which is extremely concerning.  In some departments, upward mobility is only possible whenever a position is vacated.

review_title: Mired by tradition, short sighted, and preoccupied with the small successes.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Ability to pursue some of your own work without much oversight.  Located in a place with low cost of living.  Lack of support from administration allows for departmental camaraderie
cons: University administration doesn't care about graduate researchers or teachers.  Too busy teaching undergrad what it was like when their parents were there to innovate for future generations.  University harbors culture that isn't friendly to LGBT community.

review_title: Not Bad For A Job While In School
job_title: Peer Teacher in College Station, TX
pros: It is a very good way to refresh your basics of programming. You also get an opportunity to learn form students who may come up with clever solutions to problems.
cons: The campus-wide groupthink can be a bit of a problem at times. Dealing with students who have less-than-good professors can be kind of a pain.

review_title: Welcome to Aggieland: A great place to live and work
job_title: Senior Software Applications Developer in College Station, TX
pros: We are offered valuable health/medical and life insurance benefits at an affordable cost.  Although the salaries are not stellar, the work environment is family-friendly and the community is close-knit.
cons: Parking is only available after paying a fee and not always convenient.  We are assigned to designated lots, which can be a problem when having to attend a meeting across campus.

job_title: Student Worker Evan's Library in College Station, TX
pros: Get to chose your own schedule. Very easy work, all I did was put books back on the shelf in the correct spot or shift books from one shelf to another shelf to save room for growth or organization. Get good exersize walking around so much, even more if you only take the stairs. The boss is really nice and you can talk to her about anything.
cons: Don't get to work on homework like other student worker positions. Can be boring if you are working by yourself.

job_title: Library Specialist in College Station, TX
pros: If you are a people person, this is a good place to work. Living in town, if you don't want to sling burgers or work retail, this is the best place to work.
cons: Administration does not have the front-line employee's backs. They are more interested in scoring political points with the state government. Mid level management tends to be less focus on staff and more focused on faculty. Staff really do get a short straw.

job_title: Graduate Assistant Researcher in College Station, TX
pros: Great pay, that allows you to balance school and research to reach your goals. This depends on your department and your adviser but I have had a great experience.
cons: No real cons that I can think of. As long as you do your homework on the department and the adviser you are choosing you should be fine.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: Loved working with students and increasing my teaching skills. Had many opportunities to volunteer for tasks that allowed me to build valuable skills
cons: These jobs are very time consuming. You will often have many students that are very needy, especially in lower level classes.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: There are abundant resources for performing research with, including facilities for synthesis and characterization. Access to the literature via the library is second to none. We have a steady stream of visitors that allow for the exchange of ideas.
cons: The Chemistry Building is old and there are perennial problems during the winter and during wet weather. While graduate students' stipend has increased, it is still lower than I would prefer, especially since the cost of living in College Station is increasing.

job_title: Intramural Supervisor in College Station, TX
pros: Great people to work with along with flexible scheduling made this a great job as a student. The dynamic environment allowed me to improve upon my leadership skills every day.
cons: At times the participants can be a lot to deal with and you must always remain calm despite dissent. And one would work at night. Other than that there are not many cons

review_title: Great job to have as a student!
job_title: Student Worker Reed Arena in College Station, TX
pros: Great hours, and very flexible. Everyone in the office is very nice and fun to work with. Best job to have as a student.
cons: Not too many cons that I can think of. Toughest part of the job I would say is waking up in the morning to be at the office by 7:45 am. Other than that, I can't complain.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Texarkana, TX
pros: Supportive environment.  Everyone knows everyone else. Growing and making progress.  Many long-term employees who have history and stability.  Less stable in administration, but top administrator is trying to move forward
cons: Because it is small you must be a generalist, also career opportunities are limited.  Funding is limited for research.  Location is a backwater - 3 hour drive to Dallas, 1.5 to Little Rock

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: Very flexible! I was able to make my own hours. For students, they are very understading.  If you have an interview or need to take off work for school, they won't make you go through a long list of procedures. All you have to do is give them a heads up. The work environment is also very friendly every does stuff together, they celebrate weddings, baby showers, students graduating etc.
