cons: Some processes have a lot of steps that could be taken out and still get the job done.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: The work was flawless and people were very supportive and the medical insurance was covered and the mileage was also reimbursed. There was no pressure and over all it was best experience.
cons: The shifts was in the early morning and I had to travel to different city, It is 45 miles away from my home.

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: The Cushing Library was amazing to work at as a student worker. They worked with your school schedule to maximize your work hours and when you needed time off for class projects.
cons: The Cushing Library the only con was that it was so cold in the building. It has to be that cold to preserve the books.  Remember to bring your sweater.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Amazing facilities, lots of opportunities around campus, entrepreneurial spirit, culture of aggieland (pro and con)
cons:
If you are a grad student 99% of your success depends on your advisor. I cannot stress this enough. Pick an advisor who will help you succeed and not put you down. 

Some advisors/Profs have a reputation for belittling those around them. I've heard incredibly disrespectful things said about students, post-docs, and even department staff.

review_title: Friendly campus in a nice location at a university that does cutting edge research
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: The students and staff are friendly, which makes coming to work pleasant. There is always something interesting going on around campus, since there's everything you could possibly be interested in at a university this large.
cons: Parking is awful, unless you're willing to pay for a premium permit. If you work in the middle of campus, there are no lots at all nearby, so be prepared to walk! It's also a state run institution, so pay gets capped.

review_title: Probably one of my best jobs--in retrospect
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: It didn't feel like it at the time, but I've come to appreciate how good it was to work here, having since worked for 3 other universities. Students were polite, if almost deferential, to adults.
cons: The location and culture make it difficult to recruit and retain mobile, urbane, educated faculty and staff. Bryan/College Station has a transient student and staff population, especially for junior faculty and staff whose career trajectories may make them highly sought-after elsewhere. Making and keeping friends is not always easy.

review_title: The Best Place to Work in the Area!
job_title: Business Administrator in College Station, TX
pros: A large university setting with a stable environment, most people are more laid back than in bigger cities.  Traffic can be busy, but nothing like Houston, Dallas or Austin.  Working environment is overall very satisfactory in staff level positions. Excellent benefit package!  Excellent community and comfortable living environment.
cons: The past few years... salary increases have been practically zero.  Hopefully, the salary freeze will change with this legislative session.

review_title: Amazing place to work at, with great benefits
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in College Station, TX
pros: One of the safest city, most people are very nice, lots of young people in the city making it lively. Texas A&M statistics department is among the best in the country with many distinguished professors. Great benefits and travel/equipment funding...ideal place if you wanna raise a family and houses are cheap compared to the rest of the country
cons: College Station is isolated, not that many places to have fun, you'll have to either drive to Houston, Dallas, Austin or San Antonio ...

review_title: Very religious but nice bunch; environmentally un-friendly
job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: Laid back environment, super friendly people, workload at times very relaxed
cons: The main administrative people are loud and proud about being very conservative and religious and will share their homophobic sentiments with you

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: If you can manuever into a position where you get experience that can be used to get a better job, then it is okay, but otherwise the total compensation is the paycheck.
cons: Some of the teams are hostile work environments. Don't bother trying to get help from HR if you are in one of these groups, best thing is to just get a better job somewhere else. The Chancellor seems to recognize that many staff departments are a lost cause so he is outsourcing whole departments. Seems like a step in the right direction, but in the staff point of view it is horrible. Staff are getting no notice layoffs.

review_title: Helping others to do their job easier, better and in a timely matter.
job_title: Administrative Associate IV in College Station, TX
pros: Trustworthy, Excel, Experience, Quality, Efficient
cons: Patience with those that play ignorant.

job_title: Graduate Assistant
pros:
- get to work with professors on a daily basis
- tuition free if you are in-state
- pay in-state tuition if you are from out of state
- get to work on research projects in your fields of interest
cons:
- inconsistent workload
- may work on research that does not interest you

review_title: It has been a wonderful experience
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: The funding is great they university has paid for all four semesters of my graduate fees in addition to the 1100 monthly stipend. The professors know that a graduate assistant has his own studies at a priority to what work the student is doing.
cons: There are no downsides as such if one knows how to manage time well. If not then as a graduate teaching assistant one kinda loses track of their own studies and get too involved with teaching and grading.

job_title: Cashier in College Station, TX
pros: Great work environment and opportunity for advancement. A great chance to meet a lot of new people and make a lot of new friends.
cons: A very small amount of the people that work there are not very enthusiastic about coming to work. Sometimes everything is not operating as efficient as possible.

job_title: in College Station, TX
pros: Good resources, good learning and teaching environment. People are very friendly and generally supervisors and understanding. Overall it was a good experience.
cons: Bureaucracy is the worst thing about Texas A&M University at Qatar, usually paperwork can take some time. If your research project requires items and tools from the US, then plan for a long delay of your work because of the clearance and shipping time.

job_title: Student Bus Driver in Houston, TX
pros:
-Flexible work schedule
-Very competitive pay (Starting at $12/hr)
-Useful skill (CDL-class B) which can help you land a job after college if you don't have any good career prospects yet
-Fun work environment. No other bus gig is gonna let you listen to music while you drive
cons:
-Strict attention to the rules
-They don't play favorites. This is helpful when you're new, but it can lead to you getting disciplined when you slip up after a while
-Early mornings and late nights are common. Although, they won't be back-to-back

review_title: Overall, a nice place to work and live.
job_title: Information Technology Manager in College Station, TX
pros: TAMU has good health and retirement benefits and promotes a healthy work/life balance. Additional benefits for longevity. There is a lot of free training available and many departments consider employee development important.
cons: Staff salaries below industry average, very conservative area, not much to do outside work, constant construction on campus, pay to park. TAMU encourages people to remain with the university for a long time, which can lead to stagnation. Also, being a public university, it is not very agile.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: Working at Texas A&M is a great place to gain job experience. The climate is very relaxed, and everybody is very friendly. The work-life balance is great. The health insurance and vacation/sick leave policies are also pretty good.
cons: The university system leadership is in flux, and that makes the future of the university uncertain. The pay is less than the private sector (understandably) but is inconsistent between colleges & divisions.

review_title: Student Worker in the Department of Student Activiteis
job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros:
The entire office has a great atmosphere. 
From a student worker's perspective, the management provides excellent support so long as you show enthusiasm for doing you job.
You can also do your homework when the office isn't too busy.
You gain a lot of experience dealing with people while working in a service oriented environment
cons: I worked there for several years but my pay always stayed at minimum wage.

job_title: Graduate Assistant
pros: The research is top-notch and the faculty is supportive and engaging. Excellent place to go to school. In Engineering, you basically get paid to go to school so it's worth it
cons: College station is not a bad town. It just is a college town and as a graduate student the crowd is always younger than if you were in a larger city

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Kingsville, TX
pros:
Working with the Office of the Student Access and the Department of Mathematics provided an opportunity to do what I had passion for Mentor and Tutor.
Great supervisors that will also mentor and lead you to be successful
Great relationship between students and the staffs/faculty.
I was blessed to be given the opportunity to work in these two areas.
cons: There are peak times and times when things get slow. You need to be prepared for the peak times and also make wise use of the down times.

job_title: Student Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Big public school and a diverse culture with many traditions. Great school having a huge aggie network across the globe. Proud to be a part of Aggie Network. Whoop!
cons: Basic pay given as it is a state university. Low teachers/students ratio makes it difficult to find advisor and research assistant ship or teaching assistant ship.

review_title: Don't work at the vet school
job_title: Student Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Flexible hours, opportunities for experience.
cons: I've worked at the vet school as a student assistant for almost three years now. The morale here is low and the attitude of the people you're constantly surrounded by is so bad. Management treats student workers horribly with low pay, raises are rare, and they make us work all holidays including spring break which shouldn't even be a holiday for full time staff.  People here think they have every excuse to treat student workers badly and are constantly blaming us for mistakes which aren't even our fault. Some services here overwork and underpay all of their staff including vet techs, assistants, basically anyone who isn't a doctor.

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: The job is flexible at certain times of the year and there is a lot of time off in the form of holidays such as christmas
cons: Terrible work life balance.  While you are salary you are expected at times to work until late sometimes 9-10 pm but come to the office at 8 am the next morning.  The pay is terrible considering the amount of work that you do and there is little to no employee recognition.

review_title: Choose your PhD advisor VERY carefully
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: College Station has a relatively low cost of living compared to the bigger cities in Texas.
cons: In most departments there is very little oversight of PhD advisers and the faculty have no incentive to mentor or graduate their doctoral students.  You can be stuck for years hoping someone will put pressure on your committee to get you to defense.

review_title: Excellent on campus job while still in college.
job_title: Machine Shop Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: Learn practical machining skills, staff is polite and eager to teach you if you want to learn anything complex.  The machine shop is very well maintained, and can be quite busy but is overall very safe and productive.
cons: Working while going to school may be a problem if you cannot work more than 20 hours a week, but if you can, the schedule is very flexible, and the staff will try to work within your schedule.

job_title: Researcher in Kingsville, TX
pros: Great work environment, latest technology and equipment in the labs. Excellent professors and teachers. Installations are well equipped. Staff members are friendly.
cons: Researchers are required to travel, to local ranches, out of state parks, and some occasions to foreign countries, such as Mexico. Not all requirements and facilities are paid by the university.

review_title: Can't complain about a low cal volume EMS service!
job_title: EMT
pros: Kind of like a second family, great people to work with and very knowledgable paramedics.  State of the art equipment to work with and great maintenance.  Everyone is friendly after you get to know them.  For football games, you have an automatic place on the field.
cons: Low hourly wage for student workers.  Depending on how many people are wanting to work, you may not get your desired number of hours.

job_title: Research Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: I had my own office as a Research Assistant. My boss was also very nice and flexible with my schedules and very nice. I was also given significant waiver on my tuition. Health insurance was also pretty good. Blue CROSS blue shield. i could work from home sometimes and I was almost always working online and so actually worked more than my required 20 hours
cons: One could not make friends easily with others. Some people were a bit stiff

job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: College Station is perfect for students. Projects are very interesting. Easy to do internships in bigger cities like Houston, Austin and Dallas.
cons: I didn't have any complains when I was at Texas A&M University. If I really had to talk about the downside, I would say that the pollen seasons in College Station is really bad and hinders productivity at work.

job_title: Project Manager and Systems Analyst in College Station, TX
pros: Benefits included the usual university environment, vacation, sick leave and professional development opportunities.  Texas A&M University is in a small town with small town benefits.  There is no "rush" hour to speak of.
cons: The weather is generally hot and humid.  Outdoor adventures include a battle with an environment that is poisonous, uncomfortable and generally hostile.

job_title: Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: The teacher retirement fund is nice. They also pay for a percentage of your insurance (I already had health so my vision insurance was free).
cons: Funding of some departments is so low that professors can only afford two employees. This can be frustrating if you're an entry level employee and the other employee isn't keen to train you.

review_title: Good starting point to work in US for an international student
job_title: in College Station, TX
pros: The work atmosphere is friendly and it's hostile at all. There's not much pressure from department and it's really easy to communicate with instructors and the department head.
cons: It's well organized to train new TAs and instructors.  It does not pay a fee, so every student pay 1300~1500$ for each semester. Some TA's were very irresponsible for their duties, but the department did not take any action on this issue.

review_title: Excellent and caring team and managers, upper management unreliable and short-sighted
job_title: Research Compliance Analyst in College Station, TX
pros: Great benefits and environment, good team, family-friendly flexible work schedule, wonderful clients.
cons: The system is focused on big-picture "efficiency" but while upper management salaries skyrocket, departments can't offer raises or hire enough team members to meet demand.

job_title: Head Attendant in College Station, TX
pros: Flexible hours, very understanding of the fact that students have hard obligations as far as class schedule goes.
cons: Because most other workers are students, it can be tough to get time off to study for finals. Since your coworkers are vying to get off for the same set of days usually.

job_title: Business Analyst
pros: The employees are very friendly and it is a friendly environment to work with. And you get to learn new things on work everydat
cons:
At time you may find the work not so challenging. 
Not easy to change your stream

job_title: Student Worker in College Station, TX
pros: Great opportunities. Works with college students to set up work schedule that benefits them best.
cons: There are mostly students working for the university, and every students wants the benefits that go along with the job, so job opportunities are scarce.

job_title: Graphic Designer in College Station, TX

review_title: I interviewed people through the phone  for surveys in English and Spanish.
job_title: Interviewer and PPRI in College Station, TX

Salary was $13.5 if you were bilingual and $13 for regular pay. 
You make your own schedule 
Very calm environment  
three hour shifts
cons:
it gets a little tiring talking to people because some don't answer or hand up while you are introducing yourself. 
you are in front of a computer for too long. 
you dont get to interact with your coworkers as much

job_title: Marketing Intern in College Station, TX

job_title: Senior Software Applications Developer in College Station, TX

job_title: Sport Clubs Supervisor in College Station, TX

job_title: in College Station, TX
pros:
Good way to get experience as a student instead of textbook learning
Good way to network with professors 
Got the chance to work on multiple projects and experience many different aspects of my field
cons:
No room for growth, only a temporary position
Low pay (close to minimum)
Can be repetitive (but this is common in labs so get used to it)

job_title: in College Station, TX

job_title: Assistant Director in College Station, TX

cons: The issues facing Texas AM face all US colleges.  Declining government funding and rapidly changing society make teaching and administration a challenge.

job_title: Research Assistant in College Station, TX

cons: Specific research jobs are often tied directly to grant funds and thus end when the grant ends, often times with little warning. Career counseling and advancement are lacking.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: Good people, nice work environment.  With TA position, you can pay in-state tuition, it is very money-saving.
cons: Sometimes, it is heavily workload, it is special on the middle term or final exams.  You need to balance b/w your study and TA position.

job_title: in College Station, TX
pros: it was a good college to get education.There are many oppertunities to work in texas A&M,  but it is difficult to get a job.
cons: less salary, small city, expensive residence, no raise since last couple of years, tight economical situation, very tough situation overall.

job_title: Research Associate in College Station, TX

So if you don't want to teach, most are better served moving on to industry. Benefits are not that great, as budget cuts have virtually eliminated most of the competitive benefits.

job_title: in Bryan, TX
pros: co-workers were great.. a real team atmosphere, training opportunity available, if allowed.

job_title: Resident Advisor in College Station, TX
pros:
Get money in a flexible work environment.

job_title: Summer Research Student in College Station, TX

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in College Station, TX

My research was challenging but satisfying and I found the Department and University staff very welcoming and forthcoming. I would strongly encourage people to pursue their Grad School at Texas A&M!

job_title: Business Administrator in College Station, TX

review_title: I do not Suggest Texas A&M
job_title: Research Assistant in College Station, TX

review_title: It is a good experience to study there.
job_title: in College Station, TX

job_title: Student Worker IV in College Station, TX

job_title: Senior Software Applications Developer in College Station, TX

Great city for kids and family, dynamic and fresh atmosphere of a college town.

Salaries are low compared to other Texas cities and private industry.
Slow bureaucratic system apparently ran by an old-boy network.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX

cons: The funding opportunities are limited. Some Phd students are not able to get funding. The stipend for graduate assistants is very low relative to comparable schools.

job_title: in College Station, TX
pros: It provides a very friendly environment and space to grow in whatever manner one wants. The town is very nice and provides very good housing alternatives.
cons: It is a very big system and there is very less connection between individuals and the administration. and therefore the employee feels disconnected.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX

review_title: Work was fulfilling- pay and bureaucratic leadership was frustrating and led to my resignation.
job_title: Academic Advisor II in College Station, TX

review_title: Great people but not the best location

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros:
Good Aggie's Spirit, there is no way you won't like it.

cons: I can not imagine many downsize, the only one I have is there might be not enough parking lots in campus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX

review_title: Assist students with scheduling, mapping out career, and advising on different aspects of the degree plan.

review_title: Good university for research in chemical and material science
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX

review_title: A nice place to work as a Research Assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Station, TX

review_title: A Great Job While in Undergrad Studies

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX

job_title: in College Station, TX

Great small town feel, but close to big cities like Houston, Dallas, Austin, etc.

job_title: Gar in College Station, TX

job_title: in College Station, TX

review_title: A good campus for cutting edge research. Great faculty.

review_title: Great People, not much opportunity for advancement

job_title: Research Assistant in College Station, TX

people here are nice and willing to help each other

choose your Professor carefully because the way they treat their students varies largely 
also living in this small town is boring

job_title: Student Technician in College Station, TX

job_title: Assistant Manager in College Station, TX

job_title: Research Assistant in College Station, TX

review_title: Awesome job when I was a student.

review_title: fantastic place to work and go to school

review_title: Great scientists and educators working under knee-jerk management decisions

job_title: Associate Professor in Texarkana, TX
pros:
The administration is completely inept and corrupt. 
A few faculty are very good, trying to escape, but trapped.  Others are nearing retirement and praying the place does not close before they can retire.  The remaining faculty are "the one who took the job," or should I say, "the warm body to fill the slot."  Many programs have insufficient faculty and the faculty who are present are either out-of-date, unskilled, uninformed, or just plain unbelievably bad.  The administration is uncreative and virtually incompentent for the exception of those who are absurdly corrupt.  Graduation is in the Baptist Church, led off by a prayer by the minister.   THis is not a place to start your career, but it is a place that could end your career.  The better the faculty member, the worse they are treated by the admin.  IF you attend the right church or grew up with an admin, you will likely be treated like a god.  The most talented people I knew there were actively applying for jobs, would get interviews, and mysteriously never get an offer... likely because the policy here is to give bad references to anyone who is a former or current employee.  Why?  because recruiting new faculty is absurdly difficult.  No one will take the job, and for good reason.  Most admin have no experience in academia.  The school has serious enrollment problems and has over-spent on a new campus for which the enrollment is not sufficent to support.  Students get a horrible education because the primary rule from admin to faculty is 100% retention.  Think about it.  How do you get 100% retention from a class of students who are largely enroll as a school of last resort?  Pass everyone.  We had one faculty member who was doing very good research and graduated students who were entering PHD programs, they kicked him out because he flunked some students.  Then, we had the other faculty member who was handed a program with in communications that had practically no students (fewer tahn 10).  that prof grew it, the student were getting jobs. They dumped her as she was not sufficiently corrupt.  Then we had the computer science prof who was doing a good job, was released and took a job at an R1. The majority of faculty have a very hard time finding another job because of bad-mouthing form higher-ups.  Some earn it, but those are VERY few and far between.  I swear to you, this is absoutely the worst job you could ever take.  Yes, these are the PROS!!!!  Well, the student body is actually rewarding to work with, at least the ones who try are rewarding.
cons: The town is a dying, falling apart pile of rubble (see city-data).  Anyone who can, leaves.

review_title: Aggressively Backwards, Focus is Solely on Money
job_title: Advisor in College Station, TX
pros: Very little. Staff members are able to utilize free trainings. Health insurance is expensive, but TAMU does pitch in a lot towards it and it's very good insurance.
cons:
-Salary is VERY low. Cost of living adjustments have not been done in 10 years. Housing in the   area continuously increases in price, most staff has to live outside the city limits. 
-High turnover is accepted, even shrugged off. Only the most surface, feeble attempts are made to keep employees around, and that is more for appearances than anything else.
-Offices are often moved to make way for campus construction. Moved into trailers off campus, or moldy old buildings on campus, no concessions are made for where your parking pass is located. 
-Status quo is adhered to at all costs. HR is little to no help. 
-HR and payroll are entirely impossible to get ahold of, they do not respond in a timely manner to concerns and seem to hope that instead these concerns will be forgotten?
-Lack of technological support. Staff members use the oldest office setups and even the programs and systems necessary for their work are incredibly outdated and slow. 
-No accountability for poor treatment of staff by students or faculty. Certain departments feel able to call up and yell at staff members and when supervisors are informed, it's shrugged off. If a student storms in demanding something, staff is expected to immediately hop up and cater to that student. These students are not being taught respect or anything except that they are the most important person in the world and will end up with a degree from the "best university". 
I could go on, but I'll leave it at this. Especially if you are planning on moving here from somewhere else, DO NOT. I can almost guarantee that you will regret it. College Station is a university town that got excessively built up, traffic is horrible, people are unfriendly and unwelcoming, and prices are far too high.

I hated this job,  I know that this may be one case of someone not liking working here, but I was so excited for this opportunity, and the harder I tried to work through it, the worse the experience got.
